title: 113_s2439
content:
The Act may be cited as the "NSA Internal Watchdog Act" and establishes an Inspector General for the National Security Agency. The "NSA Internal Watchdog Act" amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to elevate the status of the Inspector General of the National Security Agency. The President must nominate a person for this position within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The transition rule allows the current Inspector General of the National Security Agency to continue serving until a new appointment is made under the amended Act, without any reduction in pay. SEC. 3. ANNUAL REVIEW OF MECHANISMS FOR REPORTING EMPLOYEE OR CONTRACTOR COMPLAINTS. Amends the Inspector General Act to include a review of complaint mechanisms for employees and contractors of the National Security Agency. 

SEC. 4. SPECIAL PROVISIONS CONCERNING THE NATIONAL SECURITY AGENCY. Adds a new section to the Inspector General Act regarding special provisions for the National Security Agency. The General Counsel to the Inspector General of the National Security Agency is appointed by the Inspector General and serves as the chief legal officer, providing legal services exclusively to the Inspector General. They perform functions as prescribed and serve at the discretion of the Inspector General. The Office of the General Counsel to the Inspector General of the National Security Agency appoints legal counsel as staff. The Inspector General can compel testimony from former employees, contractors, or detailees through subpoenas. Refusal to obey a subpoena may result in consequences. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency can enforce subpoenas through a United States district court order. The Inspector General must notify the Attorney General 7 days before issuing a subpoena. Prohibitions on investigations for national security reasons must be evaluated and reported to specific committees within 7 days. The Inspector General must include in their semiannual report a description of instances where the Secretary of Defense blocked audits or investigations. When auditing surveillance programs, the Inspector General must assess their impact on civil rights and liberties. The Inspector General must assess the impact and effectiveness of surveillance programs on civil rights and liberties, and make recommendations for improvement. Reports to Congress must be available to all Members of Congress. SEC. 5. AUDIT OF SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS AND BACKGROUND INVESTIGATIONS. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency will conduct a comprehensive audit of surveillance and data collection programs, including interactions with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency will conduct an audit of surveillance programs, including interactions with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court, and report the results to congressional committees within 180 days. This does not change the Inspector General's responsibilities. The responsibility of the Inspector General of the National Security Agency to conduct audits or investigations of surveillance programs and background investigations for access to classified information remains unchanged according to the Inspector General Act of 1978.
